ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I learned law.  And I learned how to actually have a discussion with someone I disagree with where we can actually connect. 
Brad's great.  The class is defined a lot by the students in it. So feel the vibe

a lot of privacy stuff and how hard it is to paint things in black and white. how our privacy is juxtaposed with the existence of an increasingly online world (and how difficult it can be to keep your data to yourself). who our society allows to have control over their lives and their privacy.
deep dive into topics related to privacy, computer surveillance, and internet law
I learned how to defend my opinions articulately and how to read case law efficiently.
learned about cases related to privacy, control, searches and other way to relate tech to law
Critical thinking about legal concepts of privacy

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: In person is better
only strengths. Brad is great. the other students are great. i have learned so many practical things in this class that i feel i have failed to get anywhere else at yale.
material interesting and important, not too burdensome
Strengths are Brad and the students who take this class. Everyone in 185 cares so much for each persons success and treats everyones opinions with respect. No weaknesses to this class!
if you're going to take this class you've probably taken 183 with brad. it's like 183 but better

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: In person is better
we're a super close-knit group so i'm not sure that virtual learning was a huge hindrance
fine seminar
the seminar format seemed to still work very well on zoom, perhaps because only about ~9 people took the course this semester

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would strongly recommend this course to anyone who has taken Brad's other class, CPSC 183, and loved that experience.
Unequivocally yes!
absolutely. i have gotten to become closer to some of my favorite people at yale. i wouldn't trade my experiences in and from this class for the world.
yeah, it's brad.
Yes!
yes! if you liked 183, take this course. this is by far my favorite class I've ever taken at Yale

Yes, do it. You probably know what you're signing up for and you'll learn a ton. Developing a class rapport was a little tough over zoom, but we did it, and I can appreciate how that might be the difference between an okay experience and an incredible experience in a normal semester.
Yes, Brad is the best.
